newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sumitomo copper sales plunge on trading scandal.
newsitem.headline: Sumitomo copper sales plunge on trading scandal.

text.p: Japan's Sumitomo Corp said on Tuesday its refined copper sales in the first half of the 1996/97 business year ending in March plunged to 181.2 billion yen ($1.63 billion), in the wake of a major copper scandal.
This is down by 243.3 billion yen ($2.19 billion) or 57 percent against the same period of the previous year.

"Since (former chief trader) Hamanaka was dismissed in June, we've being handling only necessary copper business such as long term contracts," Sumitomo executive vice president Takehiko Yonezu told reporters.
"We have no plan to withdraw from the copper business at the moment, but are working out future strategy at the non-ferrous metal department," Yonezu said.
Before Sumitomo fired him in mid-June of this year, Yasuo Hamanaka was considered the most influential and controversial player in the world copper market.
It has blamed Hamanaka for racking up estimated losses of $2.6 billion from unauthorised copper trading, and this has been called the world's biggest-ever loss on financial markets.
Hamanaka was recently arrested on suspicion of fraud and forgery in connection with those trades.

Sumitomo recorded a net loss in the April-September half of 212.12 billion yen ($1.91 billion) on a consolidated basis, reflecting the impact of its copper losses. The firm expected a consolidated net loss of 147 billion yen ($1.32 billion) for the full business year.

Asked about its trading policy at the London Metal Exchange (LME), Sumitomo's Yonezu said: "Our copper trading at the LME was cut drastically (after the scandal broke out). But we can't carry out metal business without it."
Another Sumitomo official said, at a separate news conference, the firm expected copper sales in the full 1996/97 business year to be less than 300 billion yen ($2.7 billion).
The giant trade house also dismissed a market rumour that it was involved with an alleged unrecorded stockpile of as much as 500,000 tonnes of copper in Rotterdam warehouses.
Asked about a report last week on the possible stockpile in Europe, Yonezu said: "I have read the reports... It is not us."

The World Bureau of Metal Statistics (WBMS) released a report last week stating that statistics from 1990 to 1995 suggested a stockpile of 500,000 tonnes of copper may have been built up in Rotterdam during that time.
Traders were sceptical of the report, although some speculated such a stockpile could be connected with Hamanaka.
Hamanaka was thought by many traders to have amassed a huge amount of physical copper that he used to prop up world prices.

Many traders have speculated that he kept copper prices artificially high in recent years through skillful use of complex derivatives transactions and his iron grip on a large portion of copper stocks in London Metal Exchange warehouses.
"We're fully cooperating with overseas authorities for probing the price manipulation allegations. But I can't tell you the details about it at this stage," Yonezu said.
Late last month, the general manager of Sumitomo's legal department said they have found no evidence that Hamanaka manipulated the world copper market.
